document_data.name: Her Love For it Was Like A Plum
document_data.mainbody: '''"Her Love for It Was Like a Plum"''' was a crude ballad about the [[shadow-cursed lands]] of the [[Chionthar Valley]], written some time before the late 15{{th}} century [[DR]].
document_data.Contents:
{{quote|''Her love for it was like a [[plum]]''
''It grew so sweet within her tum''
''And with a wiggle of her bum''
''She set right out to see love done''

''A curse had made the land its lair''
''It lay o'er all like willow hair''
''Oh it could strip the body bare''
''So filled the people with despair''

''A Shadow Curse without a light''
''Yet she would kindle romance bright''
''And so in moony dark of night''
''She went to it bereft of fright''
''And hugged the curse, the wicked blight''

''Her love for it was like a plum''
''Then, so sharply, pain did come''
''It chewed her flesh like scrumptious gum''
''She trickled, she burst, she started to run.''|"Her Love for It Was Like a Plum".}}
document_data.History: In the {{YearlinkName|1492}}, a [[book]] that recorded the song was carried by one of the [[pilgrim]]s that followed the new religion of the [[Absolute]] into the shadow-cursed lands that surrounded the [[Moonrise Towers]]. The pilgrim perished to the [[curse]], becoming an [[undead]] creature of darkness, still clinging to the book.
